questions.question_text_1: If a model predicts the positive class for all observations in a binary classification problem with both positive and negative cases present, which of the following statements is true?
question_texts: If a model predicts the positive class for all observations in a binary classification problem with both positive and negative cases present, which of the following statements is true?

options.option_text: Recall is 100%, but Precision is not necessarily 100%.
Precision is 100%, but Recall is not necessarily 100%.

questions.question_text_1: The Bankruptcy Bank, one of the major lending banks, has hired you to build a credit underwriting model to help their automated lending decisions. Their definition of default is 60-89 DPD. There is historical loans data since January 1, 2021 till 31, July 2024. Which of the following is true – as of July 31, 2024?
question_texts: The Bankruptcy Bank, one of the major lending banks, has hired you to build a credit underwriting model to help their automated lending decisions. Their definition of default is 60-89 DPD. There is historical loans data since January 1, 2021 till 31, July 2024. Which of the following is true – as of July 31, 2024?

options.option_text: Jan’21– Jul’24 is used for performance data
Apl’24 – Jul’24 is used for observation data
May’24 – Jul’24 is used for performance data
Jan’21 – Jan’24 is used for observation data
Jan’21 – Apl’24 is used for observation data

question_texts: Rollrate analysis is used to determine which of the following?

options.option_text: Vintages to be used in the data
Both Vintages to be used in the data and Target variable definition

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements is true about a credit risk model with high precision?
question_texts: Which of the following statements is true about a credit risk model with high precision?

options.option_text: It correctly identifies a high percentage of non-risky customers out of all actualnon-risky cases.
It correctly identifies a high percentage of non-risky customers out of allpredicted non-risky cases.
It correctly identifies a high percentage of risky customers out of all actualrisky cases.
It correctly identifies a high percentage of risky customers out of all predictedrisky cases.

questions.question_text_1: If a credit risk model's recall is 0.7 and precision is 0.5, what can be inferred about its performance?
question_texts: If a credit risk model's recall is 0.7 and precision is 0.5, what can be inferred about its performance?

options.option_text: The model identifies 70% of all actual risky customers and 50% of its positivepredictions are correct.
The model identifies 50% of all actual risky customers and 70% of its positivepredictions are correct.
The model has a high false positive rate and a low false negative rate.
The model has a low false positive rate and a high false negative rate.

questions.question_text_1: In reject inferencing, what is typically done with the rejected cases?
question_texts: In reject inferencing, what is typically done with the rejected cases?

options.option_text: They are manually reviewed for inclusion
They are inferred and included in the model
They are used to create a separate model

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following can be a consequence of not using reject inferencing in models dealing with credit applications?
question_texts: Which of the following can be a consequence of not using reject inferencing in models dealing with credit applications?

options.option_text: Higher risk of rejecting potentially good applicants

questions.question_text_1: In a SHAP waterfall plot, what does the initial value represent?
question_texts: In a SHAP waterfall plot, what does the initial value represent?

options.option_text: The average prediction of the model
The model’s output without any feature contributions
The model’s prediction before adding any feature contributions
The overall importance of each feature

questions.question_text_1: How does SHAP facilitate global interpretability of a model?
question_texts: How does SHAP facilitate global interpretability of a model?

options.option_text: By providing exact feature importance scores for individual predictions
By aggregating local SHAP values to estimate the global importance of eachfeature across all predictions
By displaying only the top features contributing to the model’s predictions
By creating visualizations that show how features impact model accuracy

questions.question_text_1: Which statement concerning the net present value (NPV) of an investment or a financing project is correct?
question_texts: Which statement concerning the net present value (NPV) of an investment or a financing project is correct?

options.option_text: A financing project should be accepted if, and only if, the NPV is exactly equalto zero.
An investment project should be accepted only if the NPV is equal to the initialcash flow.
Any type of project should be accepted if the NPV is positive and rejected if it isnegative.
Any type of project with greater total cash inflows than total cash outflows,should always be accepted.

questions.question_text_1: Wilson's Market is considering two mutually exclusive projects that will not be repeated. The required rate of return is 13.9 percent for Project A and 12.5 percent for Project B. Project A has an initial cost of ₹54,500, and should produce cash inflows of ₹16,400, ₹28,900, and ₹31,700 for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Project B has an initial cost of ₹69,400, and should produce cash inflows of ₹0, ₹48,300, and ₹42,100, for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Which project, or projects, if either, should be accepted and why?___________________
question_texts: Wilson's Market is considering two mutually exclusive projects that will not be repeated. The required rate of return is 13.9 percent for Project A and 12.5 percent for Project B. Project A has an initial cost of ₹54,500, and should produce cash inflows of ₹16,400, ₹28,900, and ₹31,700 for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Project B has an initial cost of ₹69,400, and should produce cash inflows of ₹0, ₹48,300, and ₹42,100, for Years 1 to 3, respectively. Which project, or projects, if either, should be accepted and why?___________________

options.option_text: Project A; because its NPV is positive while Project B's NPV is negative
Project A; because it has the higher required rate of return
Project B; because it has the largest total cash inflow
Neither project; because neither has an NPV equal to or greater than its initialcost

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Financial Forensics (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts Summary**
### **1. Credit Risk Modeling & Evaluation Metrics**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Binary Classification Metrics**:
  - **Precision**: % of correctly predicted positives out of all predicted positives.
    - Formula:
      \[
      \text{Precision} = \frac{\text{True Positives (TP)}}{\text{TP} + \text{False Positives (FP)}}
      \]
  - **Recall (Sensitivity)**: % of correctly predicted positives out of all actual positives.
    - Formula:
      \[
      \text{Recall} = \frac{\text{TP}}{\text{TP} + \text{False Negatives (FN)}}
      \]
  - **F1-Score**: Harmonic mean of precision and recall.
  - **Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) Statistic**:
    - Measures the maximum separation between cumulative distributions of "goods" and "bads."
    - **KS Value** = Max(|Cumulative Goods% – Cumulative Bads%|).
    - Higher KS → Better model discrimination.

- **Capture Rate**:
  - % of "bads" (or "goods") captured in a subset (e.g., top 10%).
  - Formula:
    \[
    \text{Capture Rate} = \frac{\text{Bads in Subset}}{\text{Total Bads}} \times 100\%
    \]

- **Gains Table**:
  - Ranks observations by predicted risk, showing cumulative % of goods/bads.

#### **Key Observations from Questions:**
- If a model predicts **all observations as positive**:
  - **Recall = 100%** (all actual positives are captured).
  - **Precision ≠ 100%** (many false positives).
- **KS Statistic** is read directly from the gains table (max value in the "KS" column).
- **Roll Rate Analysis**:
  - Measures transition of accounts between delinquency buckets (e.g., 30-59 DPD → 60-89 DPD).
  - Used to define **target variables** (e.g., 60-89 DPD as "default").

---

### **2. Reject Inferencing**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Purpose**: Address bias from rejected applicants (who are often riskier but excluded from training data).
- **Methods**:
  - **Parceling**: Assume rejected applicants behave like approved applicants with similar characteristics.
  - **Augmentation**: Infer outcomes for rejected cases and include them in model training.
- **Consequences of Not Using Reject Inferencing**:
  - **Higher risk of rejecting good applicants** (false negatives).
  - **Model overestimates performance** (optimistic bias).

---

### **3. Model Interpretability (SHAP)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **SHAP (SHapley Additive Explanations)**:
  - Explains individual predictions by attributing feature contributions.
  - **Local Interpretability**: Shows how each feature impacts a single prediction.
  - **Global Interpretability**: Aggregates SHAP values to show overall feature importance.
- **SHAP Waterfall Plot**:
  - **Initial Value**: Model’s prediction **before** adding feature contributions (often the average prediction).
  - **Feature Contributions**: How each feature pushes the prediction above/below the initial value.

---

### **4. Financial Statements & Ratios**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Balance Sheet**:
  - **Liquidity**: Ability to pay short-term obligations (e.g., current ratio, quick ratio).
  - **Solvency**: Ability to meet long-term debts (e.g., debt-equity ratio).
- **Income Statement (P&L)**:
  - **Revenue**, **COGS**, **Operating Expenses**, **Net Income**.
  - **Items NOT in P&L**: Long-term debt, equity.
- **Cash Flow Statement**:
  - **Operating Activities**: Day-to-day cash flows (e.g., loan repayments).
  - **Investing Activities**: Asset purchases/sales.
  - **Financing Activities**: Debt/equity transactions.

#### **Key Ratios:**
1. **Return on Assets (ROA)**:
   \[
   \text{ROA} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Assets}}
   \]
2. **Return on Equity (ROE)**:
   \[
   \text{ROE} = \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Shareholders' Equity}}
   \]
3. **Debt-Equity Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{D/E} = \frac{\text{Total Debt}}{\text{Shareholders' Equity}}
   \]
   - **Optimal D/E ≠ 1**: Depends on industry and cost of capital.
4. **Inventory Turnover (Days)**:
   \[
   \text{Days to Sell Inventory} = \frac{\text{Inventory}}{\text{COGS}} \times 365
   \]
5. **Price-Earnings (P/E) Ratio**:
   \[
   \text{P/E} = \frac{\text{Market Price per Share}}{\text{Earnings per Share (EPS)}}
   \]
6. **Net Present Value (NPV)**:
   \[
   \text{NPV} = \sum \frac{\text{Cash Flow}_t}{(1 + r)^t} - \text{Initial Investment}
   \]
   - **Decision Rule**: Accept if NPV > 0.

---

### **5. Time Value of Money**
#### **Key Formulas:**
1. **Present Value (PV)** of a Future Sum:
   \[
   \text{PV} = \frac{\text{FV}}{(1 + r)^n}
   \]
2. **PV of Annuity**:
   \[
   \text{PV} = \text{PMT} \times \frac{1 - (1 + r)^{-n}}{r}
   \]
3. **PV of Perpetuity**:
   \[
   \text{PV} = \frac{\text{PMT}}{r}
   \]
4. **Future Value (FV)** of an Annuity:
   \[
   \text{FV} = \text{PMT} \times \frac{(1 + r)^n - 1}{r}
   \]

#### **Key Observations:**
- **Discounting**: Brings future cash flows to present value.
- **Annuity vs. Perpetuity**: Perpetuity has no end date.

---

### **6. Text Preprocessing (NLP)**
#### **Key Techniques:**
1. **Tokenization**: Splitting text into words/tokens.
2. **Lowercasing**: Converting all text to lowercase.
3. **Stopword Removal**: Removing common words (e.g., "the," "is").
4. **Stemming**: Reducing words to root form (faster, less accurate).
   - Example: "running" → "run"
5. **Lemmatization**: Reducing words to dictionary form (slower, more accurate).
   - Example: "running" → "run"
6. **Punctuation Removal**: Stripping symbols (e.g., ",", ".").

#### **Key Observations:**
- **Stemming is faster than lemmatization**.
- **Encoding is not a preprocessing technique** (it’s a feature transformation method).

---

### **7. Autocorrelation (ACF & PACF)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Autocorrelation Function (ACF)**:
  - Measures correlation between a time series and its lagged versions.
  - Used for **MA (Moving Average) model order selection**.
- **Partial Autocorrelation Function (PACF)**:
  - Measures correlation **after removing intermediate lags**.
  - Used for **AR (Autoregressive) model order selection**.

#### **Key Observations:**
- **ACF**: Pearson’s correlation between \( y_t \) and \( y_{t-k} \).
- **PACF**: Correlation between \( y_t \) and \( y_{t-k} \) **controlling for lags 1 to k-1**.

---

### **8. Capital Structure & WACC**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Weighted Average Cost of Capital (WACC)**:
  \[
  \text{WACC} = \left( \frac{E}{V} \times r_e \right) + \left( \frac{D}{V} \times r_d \times (1 - t) \right)
  \]
  - \( E \): Equity value, \( D \): Debt value, \( V = E + D \).
  - \( r_e \): Cost of equity, \( r_d \): Cost of debt, \( t \): Tax rate.
- **Beta (β)**:
  - Measures stock’s volatility relative to the market.
  - **Levered Beta**:
    \[
    \beta_L = \beta_U \times \left(1 + \frac{D}{E} \times (1 - t)\right)
    \]
  - **Expected Return (CAPM)**:
    \[
    r = r_f + \beta (r_m - r_f)
    \]
    - \( r_f \): Risk-free rate, \( r_m \): Market return.

#### **Key Observations:**
- **Optimal Debt-Equity Ratio ≠ 1**: Depends on tax shields and cost of capital.
- **Higher beta → Higher expected return**.

---

---
## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Credit Risk Modeling & Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Credit Risk Modeling] --> B[Binary Classification]
    B --> C[Precision]
    B --> D[Recall]
    B --> E[F1-Score]
    B --> F[KS Statistic]
    F --> G[Gains Table]
    G --> H[Capture Rate]
    A --> I[Reject Inferencing]
    I --> J[Parceling]
    I --> K[Augmentation]
```

### **2. Financial Statements & Ratios**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Financial Statements] --> B[Balance Sheet]
    A --> C[Income Statement]
    A --> D[Cash Flow Statement]
    B --> E[Liquidity Ratios]
    B --> F[Solvency Ratios]
    C --> G[Profitability Ratios]
    G --> H[ROA]
    G --> I[ROE]
    G --> J[Net Profit Margin]
    D --> K[Operating Activities]
    D --> L[Investing Activities]
    D --> M[Financing Activities]
```

### **3. Time Value of Money**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Time Value of Money] --> B[Present Value]
    A --> C[Future Value]
    B --> D[Single Sum]
    B --> E[Annuity]
    B --> F[Perpetuity]
    C --> G[Compounding]
    E --> H[PV of Annuity Formula]
    F --> I[PV of Perpetuity Formula]
```

### **4. Model Interpretability (SHAP)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Model Interpretability] --> B[SHAP Values]
    B --> C[Local Interpretability]
    C --> D[Waterfall Plot]
    B --> E[Global Interpretability]
    E --> F[Feature Importance]
    D --> G[Initial Value]
    D --> H[Feature Contributions]
```

### **5. Text Preprocessing (NLP)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Text Preprocessing] --> B[Tokenization]
    A --> C[Lowercasing]
    A --> D[Stopword Removal]
    A --> E[Stemming]
    A --> F[Lemmatization]
    A --> G[Punctuation Removal]
    E --> H[Faster]
    F --> I[Slower but Accurate]
```

### **6. Autocorrelation (ACF & PACF)**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Autocorrelation] --> B[ACF]
    A --> C[PACF]
    B --> D[MA Model Order]
    C --> E[AR Model Order]
    B --> F[Pearson Correlation]
    C --> G[Partial Correlation]
```

### **7. Capital Structure & WACC**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Capital Structure] --> B[WACC]
    B --> C[Cost of Equity]
    B --> D[Cost of Debt]
    A --> E[Beta]
    E --> F[Levered Beta]
    E --> G[Unlevered Beta]
    F --> H[Expected Return CAPM]
```

---
## **Key Equations Summary**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 | **Description**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Precision               | \( \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \)                                                    | % of correct positive predictions.                                             |
| Recall                  | \( \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \)                                                    | % of actual positives captured.                                                 |
| KS Statistic            | \( \text{Max} \left( | \text{Cumulative Goods\%} - \text{Cumulative Bads\%} | \right) \) | Model discrimination power.                                                   |
| Capture Rate            | \( \frac{\text{Bads in Subset}}{\text{Total Bads}} \times 100\% \)         | % of bad cases in a subset.                                                    |
| ROA                     | \( \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Total Assets}} \)                        | Profitability relative to assets.                                               |
| ROE                     | \( \frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Equity}} \)                              | Profitability relative to equity.                                              |
| Debt-Equity Ratio       | \( \frac{\text{Total Debt}}{\text{Equity}} \)                              | Leverage measure.                                                              |
| PV of Future Sum        | \( \frac{FV}{(1 + r)^n} \)                                                  | Present value of a future amount.                                              |
| PV of Perpetuity        | \( \frac{PMT}{r} \)                                                         | Present value of infinite payments.                                            |
| NPV                     | \( \sum \frac{CF_t}{(1 + r)^t} - \text{Initial Investment} \)              | Net value of an investment.                                                    |
| WACC                    | \( \left( \frac{E}{V} \times r_e \right) + \left( \frac{D}{V} \times r_d \times (1 - t) \right) \) | Weighted cost of capital.                                                      |
| CAPM                    | \( r = r_f + \beta (r_m - r_f) \)                                           | Expected return based on risk.                                                 |
| Levered Beta            | \( \beta_L = \beta_U \times \left(1 + \frac{D}{E} \times (1 - t)\right) \) | Adjusts beta for leverage.                                                     |
